You could spend your time doing much better things, like learning to cook Bucatini with mushrooms & sausage.  Hell, let me teach you how:  You'll need: -1 lb Bucatini pasta -1/2 lb Italian sausage, casings removed -8 oz sliced mushrooms -1/2 onion, chopped -2 cloves garlic, minced -1/2 cup dry white wine -1 cup chicken or vegetable broth -1/2 cup heavy cream -1/2 cup grated Parmesan cheese -2 tbsp chopped fresh parsley -2 tbsp olive oil -Salt and pepper, to taste  1. Cook the Bucatini pasta in a large pot of salted boiling water until it's al dente. Drain and set aside.  2. Heat olive oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Add the Italian sausage and cook for 8–10 minutes, breaking it up into small pieces with a wooden spoon, until it's browned and fully cooked. Remove the sausage from the skillet and set it aside.  3. In the same skillet, sauté sliced mushrooms, chopped onions, and minced garlic for 3–4 minutes, until the mushrooms are tender.  3. Pour dry white wine into the skillet and cook for 1–2 minutes, until the liquid has reduced by half.  4. Add chicken or vegetable broth to the skillet and bring it to a simmer. Let the mixture cook for 5–7 minutes, or until the sauce has thickened slightly.  5. Stir in the cooked sausage, heavy cream, and grated Parmesan cheese until the cheese has melted, and the sauce is creamy.  6. Season the sauce with salt and pepper to taste.  7. Divide the cooked Bucatini pasta onto serving plates and spoon the mushroom and sausage sauce over the top. Garnish with chopped parsley and additional Parmesan cheese, if desired.  You're done! Go prepare some nice pasta and impress your friends.

UPDATE 3: Remember "FIX PUBG"? Yeah, me neither.  Bluehole promised to FIX PUBG, and they had shown us a roadmap of all the fixes and changes they would make before the end of October. Surprise surpise... we are nearing the end of October and they haven't done much at all. The community is losing hope and the devs keep on apologizing for the terrible servers and in-game bugs.  Shame..  ------   Bluehole have just released the 12.7GB "FIX PUBG" update, with quite a lot of performance improvements and gameplay changes. They are actually doing things! The review shall stay the same, atleast for now. If they continue with the improvements and make the game stable, maybe things will change.  "FIX PUBG" is appearantly a campaing they're having, aimed at... fixing the game. You can find the roadmap  ------  There have been a few updated recently which patched things up a bit, but only a bit. Server performance is still the same and all that.  ------   Optimizing the game? Nah.... Fixing networking issues? Nah.... Fixing bugs? Nah..... Better servers? Hell no...  Adding greedy microtransactions that provide no real value? Yes!  Wrongly suing the competition? Hell yes!  Porting the game to console in a hillariously broken state for more money? ♥♥♥♥ yeah!  ----------  But that doesn't mean the game has zero good about. I'll just lay most of the stuff down here in a pro and con style:  + Engaging battle royale mode + Incredibly fun with friends + 3 large scale maps + A variety of guns and customization + Semi-weekly updates, though most of them aren't really anything significant  - Wonky movement, especially jumping (vaulting is a great addition however) - Optimization issues, even on some high-spec setups - Server issues, desync and rubberbanding - Lootboxes (most can only be opened by buying a key) - Inferior Event Pass design to other games - Ignorant Map Playlist design  - High amounts of cheater reports. I admit that i myself have never faced an actual cheater, but others aren't fortunate as me. - The devs simply not having a clue of what they're doing. (Suing the competition, ... adding new content instead of fixing the current game, porting the game to console in a broken state for that sweet microsoft money, ...)  ---------  Conclusion: The game has massive red flags, but when it works, it works really well. Hell, even I still play it, but I wouldn't necesseraly "recommend" it to anyone new to the game, not right now.

A Disaster Unfit for Competitive Play… TL;DR » If you are contemplating giving this game a try in 2023, I highly discourage playing it due to it being infested by hackers. To be quite honest, it has reached a state where it could be aptly dubbed as "Chinese Players' Hacking Grounds."  » PlayerUnknown’s Battlegrounds, better known as PUBG, burst onto the gaming scene with the intention of intense battle royale action and addictive gameplay. However, after extensive time spent playing the game, it has become clear that it is ultimately a flawed experience. With nearly a thousand hours, this review aims to highlight the major reasons why PUBG fails to deliver on its potential and falls short as a game.  Performance Issues » One of the most glaring issues with PUBG is its poor optimization and numerous performance problems. Even on high-end systems, players often encounter frustrating lag, frame rate drops, and overall instability. Six years into its release, this game still frequently crashes and displays abrupt error messages. These technical flaws significantly detract from the immersion and hinder gameplay enjoyment. Despite several updates attempting to address these issues, the game continues to suffer from persistent performance problems.  » Like any shooter game, precise hit detection is essential. Unfortunately, PUBG’s hit registration is notoriously unreliable, leading to ridiculously unfair encounters. Shots that appear to be on target often fail to register, while others seem to land miraculously. This inconsistency greatly undermines the game’s competitive integrity and can quickly frustrate even the most patient players. The game’s netcode is largely at fault here, as it causes discrepancies through delayed or inconsistent server updates that lead to inaccurately registered shots. Furthermore, the realistic bullet physics and travel time add complexity to the hit detection system, as the trajectory of bullets over long distances in real-time strikes a challenge due to the latency between what is shown on screen and what the server interprets.  » Perhaps the biggest problem with PUBG is the prevalence of hackers. Since the dawn of 2018, the game has been plagued with cheaters, and it can be undoubtedly said that every 9 out of 10 games, players will encounter a player with some sort of illegitimate advantage. Developers have struggled to combat the use of aimbots, wallhacks, and other unfair exploits, which has led to a toxic atmosphere. Although several measures have been taken such as adding anti-cheat software and frequent ban waves, the sheer number of hackers that play this game outweighs these efforts. It is important to mention that the game’s immense popularity in China has significantly contributed to a larger player base from that region, which has increased the likelihood of encountering hackers. That said, the accessibility of cheat software in the Chinese gaming market has made it incredibly easy for players to acquire and use them.  » Lastly, PUBG’s struggle to provide a balanced meta is a significant concern. Weapons play a pivotal role in determining the effectiveness and viability of different options, but unfortunately, the game’s weapon balancing has become increasingly erratic with each update. Some weapons are severely overpowered, granting a distinct advantage to those who wield them, while others pale in comparison. The awful random loot distribution exacerbates this issue, as unlucky players may find themselves on the receiving end of extremely bad luck, struggling to acquire adequate gear for battle. This tilts the playing field and removes the equal footing that battle royales are meant to provide during the early game.  Vehicle balancing also adds to the list of issues, as vehicles play a crucial role in traversing through the vast maps, heavily influencing the outcome of combat engagements. Unsurprisingly, certain vehicles have proven to be overly resilient, allowing players to exploit their durability and survive an excessive amount of damage. Countering drive-by shootings, especially with the top speeds that some cars reach, poses an incredible challenge unless properly equipped.  » Regrettably, despite PUBG’s pioneering role in the battle royale genre, its ongoing issues and lack of substantial improvements have tarnished its reputation, making it a poor choice for newcomers. Players seeking stability, balance, and enjoyment should explore alternatives like or , which have learned from PUBG’s successes and failures to provide a more refined and satisfying gameplay experience. As for the near future, the dwindling player count only indicates the game's ongoing decline.    » If so, please leave a rating. Awards are also greatly appreciated!

PUBG was in the right place at the right time to both capitalize on the burgeoning popularity of battle royales and also serve as the vanguard for the entire genre moving forward. Unfortunately, over time a combination of its competition coming out with more polished and refined BRs, alongside a series of baffling design decisions have made the game much less appealing than it was when it came out. I'll always have fond memories of dropping C-Dot and Rozhok, but the legacy of PUBG for me, unfortunately, is one of wasted potential.

After much consideration, despite still enjoying the game and having played quite a bit of it, I have decided to write my opinion about certain aspects of the game and recommend against purchasing this game from now on.  The active online community and the good decisions in some game design, particularly regarding gunplay, make PUBG one of the best and most fun online shooters out there. Sadly, other awful and catastrophic design decisions have been made in other aspects of the game.  Despite having finished its Early Access period and having received dozens of patches, with console adaptations and even a Lite version having been released, the game is still in a very poor state in performance and stability. Random errors depending on the GPU you use, unplayable framerate for just being a driver behind, unpolished physics and a poor netcode, overall make the experience mediocre at best from a technical point of view.  But the worst and biggest offence is bots. And I'm not talking about player aim bots, I am talking about the official bots added by the developers in a recent update, in patch 7.x  According to some websites, the inclusion of bots to casual matches was to make it "a little bit easier for newer players to learn", which is a fair reason. According to the developers they manually made a lot of adjustations to the bot system to make the bots feel like real players, while still performing in average slightly worse than a decent player, and some other tweaks to their pathing and loot logic would prevent bots from being simple loot farms for human players.  The problem is that the application couldn't be farthest from the theory.  For starters, the bots are very, very dumb. This doesn't come at a surprise at first considering the alleged reason they exist is solely to help newbies to learn the game. Thing is, you couldn't imagine just how BAD the bots are. Erratic in their movement, super simple pathfinding and a very thin repertory of movement patterns overall. I have literally seen them run TOWARDS the blue zone, or simply run in roads and open fields instead of taking cover, simply standing still to aim and shoot at someone. You can easily, quickly tell from the very first time you see a bot to realize that it is indeed a bot and not a human.  Then you have the loot. You'd think that with the "prevent them from being loot farms" line, that would mean that bots simply do not min-max assault + sniper rifle combinations and do not loot advanced items from crates. Well, if you thought their loot logic was.. logical, you thought very wrong. They're beyond awful at looting. Not only they blatanly ignore healing items and level 2 armor, but they choose the worst possible combinations of guns, carrying close to mid-range assault rifles as snipers and UZIs in the late game. Both healing items and level 2 armor are extremely common and easy to come with, so it makes absolute 0 sense that you'd have the bots be awfully geared for the reason of preventing them being loot farms.  And lastly and most importantly, you have their prevalence. I am not sure about the specific amount of bots that can be spawned in a single match, but there have been more matches than not where I have faced literal ZERO human players. I have had games where I've won a winner chicken dinner without having faced a single human player, having the last 2-3 remaining players, all bots, simply dying in the blue zone or just standing still waiting to get a headshot. It is an extremely underwhelming experience.  This leads me to think that the actual reason the developers have added bots is to artificially counter the drop in active players in PUBG rather than "helping newbies".  The sole inclusion of bots and their prevalence leads to matches giving an extremely bad player experience to humans. From more than 10 times I have dropped in Pochinki, not even 1 time more than 2 other human players have dropped with me. Once one of the main most active and fun early zones in the game, has been reduced to a deserted, boring city where you might headshot the ocassional bot standing still.  All of this not only affects regular players' experience by making bots simple annoyances, but they render their "teach newbies the game" argument worthless, since no one can seriously learn how to properly play the game by having the majority of the players in a match be simple bullet sponges who stand still for you to headshot them.  It gives an extremely misleading and awful image of what the PUBG experience is. It sucks for both newbies and veteran players, and make what once was a super fun game to a mixed bag of disappointing and boring experiences.  I really hope the developers seriously reconsider the inclusion of this feature.
